title: Projects
text:
DECRAOther


Gamers and Avatars: What the connection between video-gamers and their in-game avatars can teach us about their physical activity and mental health in the real world?
Many children and adults play video games for enjoyment. For those people who play too much, this may lead to difficulties at school and in their lives. Despite these negative effects of “over-gaming”, people who play too much have been shown to not talk about their problems and/or ask for help, worsening the negative consequences of over-gaming. Studies suggest that the choices a person makes about their game figure, called an avatar, can show how they feel, their exercise habits and the ways they communicate with their family. It may also indicate, how they use their mobile phones, social media, and in general, how they are in their lives.
This study aims to investigate the different profiles of people who play games, based on how they connect with their avatar. It also aims to understand whether, who the player is outside the game, and how they experience gaming, may relate to such profiles. Lastly, it aspires to understand if/how user-avatar connection profiles can inform us about one’s mental health and physical activity outside the game.
To achieve these aims, over 500 adolescent and young adult students (12-29 years old) will be recruited to the study. Over a week (7 days), participants will be asked to answer questionnaires (online), wear a Fitbit watch, that has the capabilities to collect information about their physical activity levels and install a special application on their mobile phone to monitor phone use (time on the phone). Every 6 months, over 18 months (4 times in total), these procedures will be repeated. The data collected in the current study will add vital information about how players interact with their avatar and reveal what the avatar used can tell us about the player in real life. These may assist to develop strategies that will help people continue enjoying and benefiting from gaming while reducing the dangers of over-gaming.


Decoding the Digital Phenotype of Anxiety and Depression: Using Twitter to Identify Digital Phenotypes
Background: While real-life behaviour provides the footprint for an individual’s mental health conditions, their online behaviour seems to provide equivalent reflection/evidence for the identification of such conditions, thus functioning as a “Digital Phenotype” (DP). The current project attempts to elucidate the relationship between anxiety and depression and the DP.
Aims: To examine the cyber-psychological footprint of anxiety and depression features on different aspects/ patterns of social network media usage and behaviour. Specifically, selected indicators (i.e., frequency and timing of posting, grammatical, lexical, and sentiment analysis of language in posts) will be implemented to identify specific phenotypes. Additionally, this project aims to confirm the predictive ability of the revealed phenotypes to increase accuracy of disorder identification with reduced expenditure of resources.
Project significance: Such findings will be used to inform depression and anxiety specific profiles, as informed by the users’ participation on Twitter. These profiles can be used for the assessment and treatment of people, who might be less receptive to engage with mental health services to seek help for anxiety and depression behaviours they experience.
Furthermore, considering that cyberbehaviour can be indicative of disorder-related symptomatology, predictive models employing indicators to reflect disorder-related phenotypes can aid in the accurate identification of those suffering from such disorders especially when they are unwilling or unable to address face to face assessment and intervention procedures.

title: Cyberpsychology Research Group
text:
About us
The Cyberpsychology and Online Behavior Research group was created to address the rapidly developing interest in the behavioral effects of the use of digital/online technologies.
We are a diverse team of researchers with interests in the effects of telehealth applications, excessive internet use and virtual reality on human behavior.
Our Common aim is to provide evidence and guided directions on the potentially debilitating effects interwoven with the use of digital and online applications. These effects tend to be massively accessible via a range of popular devices such as personal computers and smartphones. We combine collaboration with the digital production industry and the mental health field to transcribe empirical evidence into practice.
Our vision involves fostering positive public health outcomes, while accommodating industry growth.

Our collaborators and partners

title: Our Team
text:
VasMariaDanielTaylorDeon



Team Leader
Dr Vasileios Stavropoulos is an internationally reputable academic and clinician in the broader field of applied psychology, with an emphasis on the use-abuse of digital media and online games. His work has been acknowledged and furthered by: a) receiving the Australian Research Council Discovery Early Career Researcher Award, 2021 and; b) membership in the specialized task force for the revision of Internet Gaming Disorder as a formal diagnosis in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). Vasileios is a member of the Australian Psychological Society (APS), the APS Clinical College, a registered psychologist endorsed in Clinical Psychology by the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Authority (AHPRA), and an accredited supervisor with the same institution. Vasileios currently works as a Senior Research Fellow in the Institute for Health and Sport, Victoria University, where he leads the Cyberpsychology and Online behavior research team.
As a scientist-practitioner, Vasileios’ research questions stem from his clinical experience and adhere to the principles of person-focused developmental research. His theoretical conceptualization follows the differential susceptibility and the risk and resilience frameworks. Within this context, Vasileios’ most recent research interests move in the field of digital phenotyping for mental health. Therefore, he aims to translate one’s digital media and gaming usage patterns into information about their mental health conditions, while combining multi-method data such as psychometric scales, wearable actigraphy, mobile monitoring applications, and social media posts. He examines this data by emphasizing the longitudinal interplay between individual, contextual and digital factors that result in the development of behavior. Vasileios’ versatile modelling and psychometric skills enable him to operationalize his research questions via a range of analyses, such as item response theory, invariance, growth, mixture, and network modelling, through the use of different programs including R, HLM, M-plus, IRTpro, JASP and Jamovi.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/VasileiosStavr2
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/vasileios-stavropoulos-14234641/
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6964-4662



Data guru & tech wonder girl
Dr Maria Prokofieva is a senior lecturer in the School of Business at Victoria University (Australia). She loves data and number crunching. She works in data science and is interested in applying data science to real world problems. Her interest is at the intersection of business and psychology.
A particular passion is on digital media (aka social media) and research methods.
Business communication, digital media, what drives people’s behaviour and how to analyse it with data – just a few topics to list!
Maria is passionate about using open source – R and promotes its use through development of workshops and educational courses. She runs a RBusiness development group from R Consortium as well as she runs a CPA Australia Discussion group on Business analytics.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/m45hap
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/mariapr/
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1974-3827



Daniel Zarate is a Ph.D. candidate in clinical psychology with an emphasis on online behavioral addictions. He currently works in research-related and teaching roles, mostly teaching in psychology, counselling, and research methodologies in undergraduate and postgraduate programs. his main research interests are in the areas of clinical psychology, behavioral addictions, and complex statistical models. Additionally, his Ph.D. uses Natural Language processing to focus on decoding ‘digital phenotypes’ in mental health contexts to detect and predict psychological issues such as anxiety and depression. These projects have enabled him to develop and implement programming skills in R Studio and state-of-the-art methodologies.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/DanielZ53418111
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/daniel-zarate-5894991a4/
ORCID: https://orcid.org/my-orcid?orcid=0000-0002-1508-8637



Taylor Brown is a PhD candidate at Victoria University and a registered provisional psychologist with the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Authority (AHPRA). Taylor’s research interests include areas of (Tele)Presence, Behavioural Addictions, Psychopathology, and Psychometry. Her research explores the connection one has with their avatar and the game world, and how this might provide some information about how and who they are outside of the game. Taylor’s interest in video games stemmed from her interest as a young child, particularly in creating different worlds through Sims. This led Taylor to pursue her interest in gaming through her research.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/TaylorB79859276
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9814-3832



Deon Tullett-Prado is a PhD candidate and emerging researcher in the area of behavioural addictions and in particular Digital Addictions. His current work features investigating the line between ‘normal’ of even ‘adaptive’ social media use and ‘problematic’ or ‘Maladaptive’ Social media use - making use of advanced statistical techniques such as Latent Class Analysis, Network Analysis and Growth Mixture Modelling. Expertise includes the use of innovative and advanced statistical analyses, and in particular methods that involve profiling populations or identifying patterns of interaction in networks.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/DeonMathew3
LinkedIn: https://au.linkedin.com/in/disaster-tullett-prado-895128193
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9926-5265

title: Skills & interests
text:
The group has a strong interest in psychometrics as well as using open source software, R, to develop papers and workshops.
This way we can contribute to the community by developing reproducible research and accumulate resources for other researchers.
Our particular interests are in the following areas:

title: Skills & interests
text:
Item Response Theory
Item Response Theory (IRT) is an approach in psychometrics that is used to design, analyse and evaluate of tests, questionnaires, and similar instruments. It has wide applicability and is usually found in any studies measuring abilities, attitudes, or other variables.
This approach is based on the assumption that there is a relationship between participant’s performances on a test item and the participant’s levels of performance on an overall measure of the ability that the test item was designed to measure.
The key difference from a more classic approach is that IRT does not assume that all items are equally difficult. To incorporate scaling items IRT uses the difficulty of test items.

title: Skills & interests
text:
Exploratory and Confirmatory procedures: 
Our particular interest is on using Exploratory Structural Equation Modeling (ESEM): development of the reproducible research and packages as well as application of the EFA in cyberpsychology.
ESEM is a relatively new technique that leverages the advantages of both Exploratory/Confirmatory Factor Analysis (EFA/CFA) and Structural Equation Modeling (SEM).
Within other techniques and approaches, we are doing work in

Measurement Invariance
Multilevel Analysis
Cross-Lagged Designs

title: Skills & interests
section: Network Analysis: we live in the Net, and not only in the Web-sense
text:
Network Analysis: we live in the Net, and not only in the Web-sense
Network analysis (or Social Network analysis, SNA) is the approach to investigating social structures by using networks and graph theory. This approach reviews each phenomenon or event as a set of nodes and and links between them (i.e. ties or edges).
Our particular focus is on applying network analysis to social media data where we develop applications and packages to collect, classify, categorise social media posts and users.
But SNA has much more to offer! It can be used to examine patterns of relationships between causal factors to identify the focal event and develop a model of the more accurate perceived causal structure.

title: Skills & interests
section: Text analysis: do you read me?
text: Text analysis: do you read me?

title: Skills & interests
text:
Machine Learning and Data Mining
Machine learning is a set of methods that is used to detect patterns in data to predict future events or occurrences. It has numerous applications, including psychology and mental health. There are quite a few methods in this domain with some examples of applications, including classifying medical cases, identifying groups of online gamers, detecting patterns in online behaviour, predicting anxiety and depression, determining interactive factors that influence mental conditions.
